Los Angeles, California
Miami, Florida | Genre = [[hip hop music|Hip hop]], [[reggae fusion]] | Length = 61:48 | Label = [[Universal Republic]], [[Def Jam Recordings|Def Jam]] | Producer = Nasir Jones (also [[Executive producer|exec.]]), Damian Marley (also exec.), [[Stephen Marley (musician)|Stephen Marley]] | Misc = {{Extra chronology | Artist = [[Nas]] | Type = studio | Last album = [[Untitled Nas album|Untitled]]
(2008) | This album = '''''Distant Relatives'''''
(2010) | Next album = ''[[Life Is Good (Nas album)|Life Is Good]]''
(2011) }} {{Extra chronology | Artist = [[Damian Marley]] | Type = studio | Last album = ''[[Welcome to Jamrock]]''
(2005) | This album = '''''Distant Relatives'''''
(2010) | Next album = ''[[SuperHeavy (album)|SuperHeavy]]''
(2011) }} {{Singles | Name = Distant Relatives | Type = studio | Single 1 = [[As We Enter]] | Single 1 date = February 23, 2010 | Single 2 = Strong Will Continue | Single 2 date = April 13, 2010 | Single 3 = My Generation | Single 3 date = August 30, 2010http://www.radio1.gr/music/forthcoming_uk_singles.htm }} }} '''''Distant Relatives''''' is a collaborative [[studio album]] by American rapper [[Nas]] and Jamaican [[reggae]] artist [[Damian Marley]], released May 18, 2010, on [[Universal Republic]] and [[Def Jam Recordings]]. Production for the album took place during 2008 to 2010 and was handled primarily by Damian Marley and [[Stephen Marley (musician)|Stephen Marley]]. Fusing musical elements of [[Hip hop music|hip hop]] and reggae, ''Distant Relatives'' features lyrical themes concerning ancestry, poverty, and the plight of [[Africa]]. The album debuted at number five on the US [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] chart, selling 57,000 copies in its first week. Upon its release, ''Distant Relatives'' received positive reviews from most music critics. == Background == News of the album first came at the [[51st Grammy Awards|2009 Grammy Awards]], when Nas told MTV reporters "Right now, I'll tell you first, I'm working on an album with Damian Marley. We tryin' to build some schools in Africa with this one, and trying to build empowerment. We're tryin' to show love and stuff with this album. So, the record's â¦ all about really the 'hood and Africa also as well."{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1604589/20090209/nas.jhtml|title=Nas Confirms Kelis' Pregnancy, Talks New Album|last=Reid|first=Shaheem|date=2009-02-09|work=[[MTV News]]|accessdate=2009-04-08}} The album title derives from Nas and Marley's relationship, their shared African ancestry, and the shared ancestry of the entire human race; which musically and lyrically inspired each recording.{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/bbcom/news/nas-damian-marley-prep-collaborative-album-1003960203.story|title=Nas, Damian Marley Prep Collaborative Album|last=Concepcion|first=Mariel|date=2009-04-08|work=Billboard|publisher=[[Nielsen Company|Nielsen Business Media]]|accessdate=2009-04-09}}{{cite web|url=http://www.rap-up.com/2009/04/08/nas-damian-marley-prep-joint-album/|title=Nas & Damian Marley Prep Joint Album|last=Cline|first=Georgette|work=[[Rap-Up]]|accessdate=2009-04-29}} Leftover tracks from Nas and Marley's previous albums were originally planned for an [[extended play|EP]] based on Africa. After working together, the duo decided to record a full album together.{{cite web|url=http://music-mix.ew.com/2009/04/nas-damian-marl.html|title=Nas and Damian Marley on their 'Distant Relatives' collaboration|last=Vozick-Levinson|first=Simon|date=2009-04-22|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|publisher=[[Time Inc.|Time]]|accessdate=2009-04-29}} == Recording and production == Nas and Marley began recording in 2008; recording sessions took place in Los Angeles, California, and Miami, Florida. Marley and his brother, [[Stephen Marley (musician)|Stephen]], produced the majority of the album, using live instrumentation in the recording process. They collaborated with guest artists, including [[Stephen Marley (musician)|Stephen Marley]], [[Joss Stone]], [[Lil Wayne]], and [[K'naan]].{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/bbcom/news/nas-damian-marley-preview-album-collaboration-1003991562.story|title=Nas, Damian Marley Preview Album Collaboration On Rock The Bells Tour|last=Graff|first=Gary|date=2009-07-08|work=Billboard|publisher=Nielsen Business Media|accessdate=2009-07-08}} On the album's production, Marley told ''[[Rolling Stone]]'', "We're trying to have a sound that's reminiscent of both of us, but not exactly like either... A lot of charity albums come off corny. We want this to be something you'd play in your car."{{cite web|url=http://www.rollingstone.com/news/story/26796184/spring_music_preview_june|title=Spring Music Preview: June|date=2009-03-20|work=Rolling Stone|publisher=[[Jann Wenner|Wenner Media]]|accessdate=2009-04-08}} == Music == Fusing [[hip hop music|hip hop]] and [[reggae]] musical elements, Marley and Nas also incorporated [[sample (music)|samples]] from African music into the album. The album's lyrical content heavily revolves around themes concerning Africa, from ancestry and poverty,{{cite web|url=http://exclaim.ca/articles/generalarticlesynopsfullart.aspx?csid1=131&csid2=844&fid1=37732|title=Nas and Damian Marley Become Distant Relatives, Join Rock the Bells Tour|last=Thiessen|first=Brock|date=2009-04-08|work=[[Exclaim!]]|accessdate=2009-04-29}} with [[social commentary]] of the United States and Africa.{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.co.uk/artists/nas/news/112307-nas-announces-damian-marley-album|title=Nas Announces Damian Marley Album|date=2009-04-08|work=[[MTV One]]|accessdate=2009-04-29}}{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1608773/20090407/id_3108857.jhtml|title=Nas And Damian Marley Team Up For Rock The Bells Tour, Joint Album|last=Reid|first=Shaheem|date=2009-04-07|work=MTV News|accessdate=2009-04-29}} The track "Count Your Blessings" reflects on the plight of Africa. == Release and promotion == [[File:Nas and Damian Marley performing in Wellington Photo By Brady Dyer.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Nas and Marley performing in Wellington, New Zealand, 2011]] The album was released May 18, 2010 on [[Universal Republic]] and [[Def Jam Recordings]].{{cite web|url=http://www.hiphopdx.com/index/news/id.10839/title.damian-marley-speaks-about-lil-waynes-distant-relatives-feature|title=Damian Marley speaks|last=Marley|first=Damian|date=2010-02-18|work=Reggaeville|accessdate=2010-02-18}} Its proceeds will go to a project in Africa, with the possibility of building a school in the [[Congo Basin|Congo]]. === Panel discussion === At a sold-out panel discussion on the [[African diaspora]] and its relation to music, sponsored by [[National Geographic]], Damian and Stephen Marley and Nas were among the several hip hop and reggae musicians voicing their solidarity. The discussion focused on the collaborations between artists of the two genres, and highlighted the ''Distant Relatives'' project.The Source, [http://www.thesource.com/2009/12/nas-and-damian-marley-distant-relatives-coming-in-2010/ Nas and Damian Marley Distant Relatives Coming in 2010], ''TheSource.com'', 14 December 2009. Accessed 6 January 2010. === Singles === The first single, "[[As We Enter]]", was released on [[iTunes Store|iTunes]] on February 23, 2010.[http://www.rap-up.com/2010/02/11/single-cover-nas-damian-jr-gong-marley-as-we-enter/ Single Cover: Nas & Damian âJr. Gongâ Marley â âAs We Enterâ.] ''Rap-Up.'' It has so far peaked at #10 on the iTunes Hip Hop/Rap charts and #41 on the iTunes Music charts. The single debuted at number 39 on the [[UK Singles Chart]].[http://www.webcitation.org/5q3Bbo7Zy The Official UK Top 40 Singles Chart - 23 May 2010]. [[BBC Online]]. Retrieved on 2010-05-27. "Strong Will Continue" is featured in the soundtrack for [[2010 FIFA World Cup South Africa (video game)|2010 FIFA World Cup video game]]. "My Generation" was released in the United Kingdom on August 30, 2010. == Reception == === Commercial performance === The album debuted at number five on the US [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] chart with first-week sales of 57,000 copies.Caulfield, Keith. [http://www.billboard.com/news/glee-stops-the-show-at-no-1-stones-come-1004094028.story#/news/glee-stops-the-show-at-no-1-stones-come-1004094028.story 'Glee' Stops the Show at No. 1, Stones Come in Second On Billboard 200]. ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]''. Retrieved on 2010-05-26. It serves as Nas's tenth top-ten album and Marley's second top-ten album in the United States. The album also entered at number four on ''[[Billboard charts|Billboard]]''{{'}}s [[Top Digital Albums|Digital Albums]],[http://www.billboard.com/charts/digital-albums?chartDate=2010-06-05#/charts/digital-albums?chartDate=2010-06-05 Digital Albums - Week of June 05, 2010]. ''Billboard''. Retrieved on 2010-05-27. and at number one on its [[R&B/Hip-Hop Albums]],[http://www.billboard.com/charts/r-b-hip-hop-albums?chartDate=2010-06-05#/charts/r-b-hip-hop-albums?chartDate=2010-06-05 R&B/Hip-Hop Albums - Week of June 05, 2010]. ''Billboard''. Retrieved on 2010-05-27. [[Top Rap Albums|Rap Albums]],[http://www.billboard.com/charts/rap-albums?chartDate=2010-06-05#/charts/rap-albums?chartDate=2010-06-05 Rap Albums - Week of June 05, 2010]. ''Billboard''. Retrieved on 2010-05-27. and Reggae Albums charts.[http://www.billboard.com/charts/reggae-albums?chartDate=2010-06-05#/charts/reggae-albums?chartDate=2010-06-05 Reggae Albums - Week of June 05, 2010]. ''Billboard''. Retrieved on 2010-05-27. Internationally, ''Distant Relatives'' attained some chart success.{{cite web|title=Nas & Damian Marley - Distant Relatives|url=http://www.ultratop.be/nl/showitem.asp?interpret=Nas+%26+Damian+Marley&titel=Distant+Relatives&cat=a|publisher=[[Ultratop]]|accessdate=May 27, 2010}}[http://acharts.us/album/55241 Album Performance: ''Distant Relatives'']. acharts. Retrieved on 2010-05-27. It entered at number 33 on the [[European Top 100 Albums]] chart.[http://www.webcitation.org/5q3EZrsmZ European Albums - Week of June 05, 2010]. ''Billboard''. Retrieved on 2010-05-27. In the United Kingdom, it debuted at number 30 on the [[UK Albums Chart]] and at number four on the [[UK R&B Chart|R&B Albums Chart]].[http://www.webcitation.org/5q3Biqr5J The Official UK Top 40 Albums Chart - 23 May 2010]. [[BBC Online]]. Retrieved on 2010-05-27.[http://www.webcitation.org/5q3BrpckH UK Top 40 RnB Albums - 23 May 2010]. BBC Online. Retrieved on 2010-05-27. In Canada, the album entered at number 10 on the [[Canadian Albums Chart|Top 100 Albums]] chart.[http://www.webcitation.org/5q3Byk1eP Top 100 - For the Week Ending 20 May, 2010]. [[Jam!]]. Retrieved on 2010-05-27. In Germany, it debuted at number 38 on the [[Media Control Charts]],[http://www.webcitation.org/5q4dBNnE7 Album Top 50 KW 20 - GÃ¼ltig ab 28.05.2010]. MTV. Retrieved on 2010-05-28. and in the Netherlands, the album debuted at number 72 and peaked at number 65 on the [[MegaCharts|Mega Album Top 100]]. === Critical response === {{Album ratings | rev1 = [[Allmusic]] | rev1Score = {{Rating|4|5}} | rev2 = [[Robert Christgau]] | rev2Score = (A-) | rev3 = ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' | rev3Score = (B+) | rev4 = ''[[The Guardian]]'' | rev4Score = {{Rating|4|5}} | rev5 = ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' | rev5Score = {{Rating|2.5|4}} | rev6 = [[Pitchfork Media]] | rev6Score = (6.1/10) | rev7 = [[PopMatters]] | rev7Score = (7/10) | rev8 = ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' | rev8Score = {{Rating|3|5}} | rev9 = [[Slant Magazine]] | rev9Score = {{Rating|4.5|5}} | rev10 = ''[[The Village Voice]]'' | rev10Score = (mixed) }} ''Distant Relatives'' received positive reviews from most music critics. At [[Metacritic]], which assigns a [[Standard score|normalized]] rating out of 100 to reviews from mainstream critics, the album received an [[weighted mean|average]] score of 73, based on 23 reviews, which indicates "generally favorable reviews".[http://www.metacritic.com/music/artists/nasanddamianmarley/distant-relatives ''Distant Relatives'' Reviews, Ratings, Credits, and More]. [[Metacritic]]. Retrieved on 2010-05-18. [[Allmusic]] writer David Jeffries complimented its themes concerning Africa, calling it "one purposeful monster and a conceptional bull's eye that fully supports its title".Jeffries, David. [{{Allmusic|class=album|id=r1738526|pure_url=yes}} Review: ''Distant Relatives'']. [[Allmusic]]. Retrieved on 2010-05-18. ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]''{{'}}s Simon Vozick-Levinson commended Nas's and Marley's "righteous tones that only occasionally lapse into preachiness".Vozick-Levinson, Simon. [http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,20368555,00.html Review: ''Distant Relatives'']. ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]''. Retrieved on 2010-05-18. [[Sputnikmusic]]'s Ryan Flatley gave the album four out of five stars and commented that "Nas and Damian Marley are a formidable pairing, seemingly on the same level throughout most of the album in thought and overall presence".Flatley, Ryan. [http://www.sputnikmusic.com/album.php?reviewid=36908 Review: ''Distant Relatives'']. [[Sputnikmusic]]. Retrieved on 2010-05-19. Steve Jones of ''[[USA Today]]'' gave it three-and-a-half out of four stars and called it "[a] potent and often provocative collaboration".Jones, Steve. [http://www.usatoday.com/life/music/reviews/2010-05-18-listen18_ST_N.htm Review: ''Distant Relatives'']. ''[[USA Today]]''. Retrieved on 2010-05-18. Dave Simpson of ''[[The Guardian]]'' gave the album four out of five stars and described its music as "thoughtful, sincere, weighty stuff, tackling subjects from African poverty to the diamond trade without sounding preachy or schmaltzy".Simpson, Dave. [http://www.guardian.co.uk/music/2010/may/13/nas-damian-marley-distant-relatives-cd-review Review: ''Distant Relatives'']. ''[[The Guardian]]''. Retrieved on 2010-05-18. Jesal Padania of RapReviews gave ''Distant Relatives'' a 10 out of 10 rating and commented that "neither Nas nor Marley come across too preachy [...] yet they also manage not to patronise Africa".Padania, Jesal. [http://www.rapreviews.com/archive/2010_05_distantrelatives.html Review: ''Distant Relatives'']. RapReviews. Retrieved on 2010-05-20. In contrast, ''[[Spin (magazine)|Spin]]''{{'}}s J. Gabriel Boylan gave the album a six out of 10 rating and found its "revelatory message blunted by digressions".Boylan, J. Gabriel. [http://www.spin.com/reviews/nas-damian-jr-gong-marley-distant-relatives-universal-republic Review: ''Distant Relatives'']. ''[[Spin (magazine)|Spin]]''. Retrieved on 2010-05-18. Sean Fennessey of ''[[The Village Voice]]'' viewed it as "rudimentary", calling the album "a tasteful affair full of uninteresting revelations and self-serious proclamations".Fennessey, Sean. [http://www.villagevoice.com/2010-05-18/music/back-to-africa-with-nas-and-damian-marley Review: ''Distant Relatives'']. ''[[The Village Voice]]''. Retrieved on 2010-05-19. ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' writer Jeff Weiss commented that the album "vacillates between the dreary and dynamic" and viewed its "didacticism" as a weakness, stating "leadened by reductive philosophies and crippling self-seriousness, the record often feels overly ponderous".Weiss, Jeff. [http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/music_blog/2010/05/album-review-nas-and-damian-marleys-distant-relatives.html Review: ''Distant Relatives'']. ''[[Los Angeles Times]]''. Retrieved on 2010-05-18. [[Pitchfork Media]]'s Tom Breihan found the album's lyrics trite and stated "Nas and Marley fall into a sort of middlebrow funk, kicking overripe platitudes over sunny session-musician lopes and letting their self-importance suffocate their personalities [...] When these guys stop trying to be positive and just ''vent'', they do great things".Breihan, Tom. [http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/14265-distant-relatives/ Review: ''Distant Relatives'']. [[Pitchfork Media]]. Retrieved on 2010-05-21. Nathan Rabin of ''[[The A.V. Club]]'' called it "an Afrocentric manifesto sometimes loaded down by the weight of its noble ambitions".Rabin, Nathan. [http://www.avclub.com/articles/nas-and-damian-marley-distant-relatives,41475/ Review: ''Distant Relatives'']. ''[[The A.V. Club]]''. Retrieved on 2010-05-25. While noting that its "live-band reggae sometimes feels sleepy", ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' writer Christian Hoard stated "Nas is there to slap the track awake".Hoard, Christian. [http://www.rollingstone.com/music/reviews/album/;kw=%5B14339,153202%5D Review: ''Distant Relatives'']. ''[[Rolling Stone]]''. Retrieved on 2010-05-18. Jesse Serwer of ''[[The Washington Post]]'' commented that Nas "is often guilty of coasting [...] leaves the heavy lifting to Marley", but praised each artists' "inspired lyrical performances".Serwer, Jesse. [http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/05/17/AR2010051703675.html Review: ''Distant Relatives'']. ''[[The Washington Post]]''. Retrieved on 2010-05-18. David Amidon of [[PopMatters]] stated "The collision between hip-hop and reggae is a little overblown [...] but the alchemy between Nas and Junior Gongâs voice is obvious and engenders a strong sense of unity".Amidon, David. [http://www.popmatters.com/pm/review/125979-nas-damian-marley-distant-relatives Review: ''Distant Relatives'']. [[PopMatters]]. Retrieved on 2010-06-01. [[BBC Online]]'s Mike Diver complimented "the balance between Zion-celebrating lyricism and the real-life observations that accompany hip hop".Diver, Mike. [http://www.bbc.co.uk/music/reviews/9vgw Review: ''Distant Relatives'']. [[BBC Online]]. Retrieved on 2010-05-18. [[Slant Magazine]]'s M.T. Richards called the album "a bright, richly cultured work" and praised its themes of humanity and humility, writing that it "shines with passion and zeal, both in its content and production, which oozes earthy warmth".Richards, M.T. [http://www.slantmagazine.com/music/review/nas-and-damian-marley-distant-relatives/2122 Review: ''Distant Relatives'']. [[Slant Magazine]]. Retrieved on 2010-05-25. In his consumer guide for [[MSN Music]], critic [[Robert Christgau]] gave ''Distant Relatives'' an A- rating, indicating "the kind of garden-variety good record that is the great luxury of musical micromarketing and overproduction".[http://www.robertchristgau.com/xg/bk-cg90/grades-90s.php CG Grades 1990- : Key to Icons]. Robert Christgau. Retrieved on 2010-02-15. Christgau complimented Marley's production and the album's themes, stating "The result is an exceptionally melodic reggae album that's intensified by rapping devoid of dancehall patois and a hard edge unknown to roots revivalism. The result is also an exceptionally political hip-hop album that's most convincing when it doesn't multiply Afrocentric distortion by Rastafarian reasoning".Christgau, Robert. "[http://www.webcitation.org/5qAa4sDML Consumer Guide: ''Distant Relatives'']". [[MSN Music]]: June 2010. == Track listing == * All tracks were produced by Damian Marley except tracks 4, 9, and 11, produced by Stephen Marley. {{tracklist | writing_credits = yes | title1 = [[As We Enter]] | writer1 = [[Nas|Nasir Jones]], [[Damian Marley]], [[Mulatu Astatke]] | length1 = 2:58 | title2 = Tribes at War | note2 = featuring [[K'naan]] | writer2 = Jones, Marley, [[K'naan|Keinan Warsame]] | length2 = 4:30 | title3 = Strong Will Continue | writer3 = Jones, Marley | length3 = 6:02 | title4 = Leaders | note4 = featuring [[Stephen Marley (musician)|Stephen Marley]] | writer4 = Jones, Marley, Stephen Marley | length4 = 4:20 | title5 = Friends | writer5 = Jones, Marley | length5 = 4:49 | title6 = Count Your Blessings | writer6 = Jones, Marley | length6 = 4:24 | title7 = Dispear | writer7 = Jones, Marley | length7 = 5:53 | title8 = Land of Promise | note8 = featuring [[Dennis Brown]] | writer8 = Jones, Marley, Dennis Brown | length8 = 3:54 | title9 = In His Own Words | note9 = featuring Stephen Marley | writer9 = Jones, D. Marley, S. Marley | length9 = 5:00 | title10 = Nah Mean | writer10 = Jones, Marley | length10 = 4:09 | title11 = Patience | writer11 = Jones, Marley, [[Amadou & Mariam|Amadou Bajayoko, Mariam Doumbia]] | length11 = 5:46 | title12 = My Generation | note12 = featuring [[Joss Stone]] & [[Lil Wayne]] | writer12 = Jones, Marley, [[Lil Wayne|Dwayne Carter]] | length12 = 4:00 | title13 = Africa Must Wake Up | note13 = featuring K'naan | writer13 = Jones, Marley, Warsame | length13 = 6:41 }} {{tracklist | collapsed = yes | headline = iTunes bonus track | writing_credits = yes | title14 = Ancient People | note14 = featuring [[Junior Reid]] | writer14 = Nasir Jones, Damian Marley, Junior Reid | length14 = 4:35 }} ; Sample credits List of [[Sampling (music)|samples]] used for ''Distant Relatives'' adapted from liner notes.Track listing and liner notes per ''Distant Relatives'' album * '[[As We Enter]]' contains samples of [[Mulatu Astatke]]'s song ''Yegelle Tezeta''. * 'Tribes at War' contains a sample from ''Tribal War'' by Earl Lowe. * 'Friends' contains a sample from ''Undenge Uami'' by David ZÃ©. * 'Land Of Promise' contains a sample from ''Promised Land'' by [[Dennis Brown]]. * 'Nah Mean' contains a sample from ''Kurikute'' by Sara Chaves. * 'Patience' contains a sample from ''Sabali'' by [[Amadou & Mariam]] from the album [[Welcome to Mali]]. * 'My Generation' contains a sample from ''Generation'' by [[Ziggy Marley]]. == Personnel == Credits for ''Distant Relatives'' adapted from [[Allmusic]].[{{Allmusic|class=album|id=r1738526/credits|pure_url=yes}} Credits: ''Distant Relatives''].
